item.title: Overwatch‚Äôs ‚ÄòSame Face Syndrome‚Äô Has Claimed Another Victim
item.content:encoded:
Overwatch‚Äôs character design has gotten a bit homogeneous over the years, and fans have taken notice of it. Specifically, the women of Blizzard‚Äôs hero shooter have suffered from a bit of ‚Äúsame face syndrome‚Äù for years, with characters like Widowmaker, Ashe, and Freja being nearly identical in some skins. However, it‚Äôs gotten especially bad for the game‚Äôs East Asian heroes since Kiriko came onto the scene in 2022. Now Anran, one of the new heroes joining the game next week, is the latest victim of this phenomenon.

Anran is a fire-wielding hero and the sister of the game‚Äôs water-bending support hero Wuyang. As such, she appeared in animated trailers, comics, and other lore before she was implemented into the game itself. Before her in-game appearance, she was depicted with a longer nose and sharper features, and overall had a distinct face compared to other characters on the roster. Now that we‚Äôve seen her in the game itself, however, fans have pointed out that her face is much more round and her nose has been shrunken down to the same button nose Kiriko and Juno have.

The similarities are so striking that some fans are joking she looks like she‚Äôs an alternate skin for Kiriko. The comparison between Anran‚Äôs old face and her new one is pretty stark, but seeing Kiriko or Juno‚Äôs face next to her current appearance is when the issue really becomes apparent. She looks less like Wuyang‚Äôs sister than she once did.

"got your nose!" but it's anran's in-game model

Fans have created some edits that try to recapture Anran‚Äôs original look and they show how, with just a few tweaks, Anran can not only look like she once did, but can look pretty distinct in a game in which several characters look like each other.

item.title: Nintendo Covers Up Violence With Hilariously Bad Gameplay
item.content:encoded:
Usually, trailers for upcoming games tend to show good gameplay. You know, things like attacks that land and shots that actually hit their targets‚Äîstuff that might get players excited about the idea of being good at a game. But when promoting two of the biggest third-party games coming to Switch, Nintendo has thrown that idea out the window, presumably to avoid sullying its family-friendly image with gory violence. 

During Thursday‚Äôs Nintendo Partner Direct, Nintendo showed off Resident Evil Requiem and Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, two games headed to its new portable console in the next few months. What stood out most about these segments wasn‚Äôt the visual quality of the two blockbusters running on less powerful hardware, however, but how terrible whoever was capturing the footage was at playing the games.

The Direct‚Äôs trailers for both games were full of missed shots and poorly-timed attacks, as pointed out by former Kotaku EIC Stephen Totilo and others. One shot from the Requiem trailer showed Leon Kennedy picking up a zombie‚Äôs chainsaw to fight off enemies only to miss and hit the railing on a bed, causing sparks to fly. Another shot from the Great Circle trailer showed Indiana Jones missing a boat full of Nazis and hitting the water below them instead.

The Requiem trailer is especially funny to watch‚Äîthe narrator raves about Leon‚Äôs ‚Äúphysical prowess‚Äù and how ‚Äúhe can fire from a distance using handguns and rifles‚Äù over clips of him missing shots by literal feet. Compared to a recent Capcom trailer for Requiem, which has no problem showing some pretty graphic stuff, it seems clear Nintendo went out of its way to hide the violence in its latest showcase. 

Nintendo hasn‚Äôt been very keen on showing violence in previous Directs, either. When it announced a Switch port of The Witcher 3 during its Direct at E3 2019, it edited out a clip of the game‚Äôs notorious hanging tree that was shown in online uploads of the trailer in some regions.

Other trailers for more violent games that have been ported onto Nintendo systems, like Cyberpunk 2077, have received more atmospheric trailers that avoid showing gameplay. Some trailers haven‚Äôt been shown at all. The 2017 Direct announcement for Wolfenstein 2, a shooter about murdering tons of Nazis, lacked a trailer entirely and was revealed only with a still image of key art. And, during the same Direct, gameplay for Doom featured more apparently intentionally bad gameplay, clips in which the player fires off to the side of enemies without landing any hits alongside one shot where the player is about to be attacked and‚Ä¶does nothing at all.

Contrast that with how the developers themselves sometimes show their games being played on Nintendo‚Äôs consoles. Here‚Äôs a CD Projekt Red trailer for Cyberpunk 2: Ultimate Edition showing off Joy-Con motion controls. It shows a woman mimicking the real-life hand gesture to throw a grenade whose explosion proceeds to decapitate the enemy on screen. Later she frantically slashes the air to slice through enemies with a katana. No one in the video misses a single kill and they‚Äôre all smiling while they do it. 

Putting smiles on players‚Äô faces is Nintendo‚Äôs corporate mission, but not with bullets and blood, apparently, at least when the Nintendo Direct cameras are rolling. We don‚Äôt have confirmation from Nintendo that it‚Äôs an intentional policy, but it‚Äôs certainly a recurring theme. However, it‚Äôs clear that Nintendo at least has a complicated relationship with the trailers for M-rated games, more of which are getting ported to Switch 2 every day. 

While today was certainly an embarrassing day for poor Leon Kennedy, as a big gamer who could definitely be a better gamer myself, I at least felt a little represented by the horrible gameplay shown off.

item.title: Pok√©mon Accidentally Finds The Perfect Way To Troll Scalpers
item.content:encoded:
For over a year, buying booster packs of Pok√©mon cards on the official Pok√©mon Center website has required either the most extraordinary luck, or a bot. When new stock is added to the site, it very quickly collapses under the weight of incoming traffic, leading to error messages or queues that never resolve. Any who do manage to get in before the site goes down are limited by strict purchase restrictions, except of course for those running the bots that are able to scoop up the stock in milliseconds. So was today‚Äôs peculiar decision to bundle the enormously popular Surging Sparks booster boxes with the never-wanted and very bulky Pok√©mon Academy boxes a deliberate troll of the scalpers by The Pok√©mon Company?

Surging Sparks is the set that‚Äôs generally considered to be the beginning of the current frenzy that‚Äôs seen Pok√©mon cards become almost impossible to buy for the last 15 months, where rocketing resale prices have led to scalping ruining the hobby for so many, and indeed strings of robberies at many specialist retailers around the world. Its restock today on the U.S. Pok√©mon Center website was therefore something of a surprise‚Äîoccurring without promotion and of course inevitably selling out before most were aware it was even happening. Except, rather than these 36-pack containers appearing for the usual price of around $160, today‚Äôs booster boxes were all bundled with the latest edition of the Battle Academy, a hefty $20 box that‚Äôs designed to introduce new players to the table-top card game, and all for the undiscounted price of $180.

If you‚Äôre already familiar with the Pok√©mon TCG, you‚Äôve likely already snorted a laugh at this. For everyone else, it‚Äôs important to know that the Battle Academy is to Pok√©mon cards what the Fisher Price telephone is to the iPhone. It contains a chunky playing board, push-out cardboard counters, and three 60-card decks with special, numbered cards that don‚Äôt feature the standard Pok√©mon card back designs, nor even a single holo among them. Even better, the Battle Academy hasn‚Äôt been updated in so many years that they still sport the late 2010‚Äôs Pok√©mon V cards. They are, in the scheme of collecting, worthless.

This has to be a troll, right? While it won‚Äôt have cost any more in shipping (the Pok√©mon Center is unreasonably good on this, waiving shipping costs for purchases over $20), it‚Äôs going to be such an epic pain in the ass for the scalpers, as their every shipment arrives with this enormous extra box of stuff they don‚Äôt want or need, and most of all, cannot resell. It‚Äôs an extra $20 too, which is just enjoyably inconvenient.

You could argue that this is also screwing over legitimate customers, and that‚Äôs sadly true. However, for independent card stores being repeatedly let down by The Pok√©mon Company‚Äôs official retail suppliers (according to multiple store owners I‚Äôve spoken to in the UK since stock shortages began, the company is allegedly prioritizing larger retail chains over them) it‚Äôs a fantastic deal, given they can also sell the Battle Academy boxes to their younger customers.

It‚Äôd be far better to see the Pok√©mon Center website actually spending the money to build an infrastructure that can cope when it stocks new TCG cards, but in the meantime, if this really was a way to just irritate scalpers, it‚Äôs hard not to give over a little kudos.

item.title: Sony‚Äôs New Live-Service Game Is Coming At Just The Worst Possible Time
item.content:encoded:
Earlier today, PlayStation and Guerrilla revealed Horizon Hunters Gathering, the next entry in the popular post-apocalyptic franchise. But this spin-off is a multiplayer-focused online co-op action game that looks a lot like Monster Hunter meets Destiny. It will receive updates post-launch, and oh, wait, this is a live-service game. Oh no, this was a bad time to announce Hunters Gathering.

I‚Äôm not sure a colorful, cartoonish online-only spin-off of the photorealistic solo single-player open-world series Horizon would have been a smash hit with terminally online fans at any point. But right now, of all times, feels one of the worst possible moments to reveal Hunters Gathering to a world wide web primed to make a Kombucha Girl face at everything it‚Äôs doing. The last two years have been littered with the corpses of failed, cancelled, or still-dying live-service games. A lot of players are, understandably, tired of these things and unsure of whether they should even invest any time into caring, as so many seem to flop or shut down.

The hunt is on.

Step into the world of Horizon Hunters Gathering, a new co-op action game from Guerrilla coming to PS5 and PC: https://t.co/TNWH4oRX2Q pic.twitter.com/BCjSquv30R

‚Äî PlayStation (@PlayStation) February 5, 2026

It was just last month that Highguard launched and was then immediately trashed by a large portion of players. The live-service PvP shooter debuted at the Game Awards, launched with over 90k active players on Steam, and now, less than two weeks after launch, is struggling to reach 5,000 players and is nowhere to be seen on any of my social feeds. Before that, Concord, a previous attempt by Sony to make a live-service game, infamously crashed and burned in less than two weeks. Marathon, the next game from PlayStation-owned Bungie, has had a very rocky rollout ever since it confirmed it was an online-only live-service experience, making me nervous about its future even as sentiment online seems to be slowly rebounding in its favor.

There are so many more live-service games that seem to be struggling to exist in an era when most people are just playing Roblox, Fortnite, GTA Online, or DOTA 2 forever. As reported by TheGamer, many of the live-service games launched in 2025 have lost most of their players, according to SteamDB. And while there are a few recent exceptions, like Arc Raiders and Marvel Rivals, it is really, really hard to break into the market and stay around. Even brief bright spots, like last year‚Äôs mini-breakout MOBA Supervine, eventually lose steam.

All of these attempts to carve out a sustainable multiplayer niche over the last two years have whittled down players‚Äô patience. At this point, every live-service multiplayer thing gets dunked on relentlessly the moment it‚Äôs announced. Sure, some of that negativity is just assholes drafting off the ‚Äúhate everything‚Äù digital ecosystems on TikTok and YouTube. But a lot of it is also just people tired of more games that ask a ton of their players without first earning it, only to eventually pay it back with a shutdown notice screenshot on social media.

This is the environment that Sony has announced Horizon Hunters Gathering into, and it shouldn‚Äôt shock anyone that a lot of the reactions to the game are people saying they have zero interest or actively calling it bad. Can you blame them? The last two years have shown that live-service games are prone to failure, likely to collapse shortly after launch, and not worth checking out if you already play one or two of them, like Fortnite. Maybe that‚Äôs why they slipped it out in a PlayStation Blog post instead of a proper State of Play showcase.

So, while I think Hunters Gathering looks neat and could be fun, I‚Äôm well aware that one day I‚Äôll likely be writing a story about how it‚Äôs no longer getting updates and is shutting off the in-game microtransaction shop. You‚Äôll read that headline on X or Reddit, go ‚ÄúOh right, that game‚Ä¶‚Äù and then just keep scrolling by. It‚Äôs hard to get too excited about a new game, even from a PlayStation studio, when that fate already feels sealed. Maybe especially from a PlayStation studio.

item.title: Resident Evil Requiem Amiibo Does The Impossible: Makes Leon Ugly
item.content:encoded:
You know, if you‚Äôre ever looking for an example of the power of human artistry, you can typically look to incredible sculptures and statues that depict the human form like David by Michelangelo or the work of Rodin. But these pieces have the advantage of not being mass produced for people to buy and stick on the Nintendo system to unlock cosmetics. The Leon Kennedy Resident Evil Requiem amiibo doesn‚Äôt have such luxuries, but it nonetheless accomplishes something remarkable as well: it somehow finally makes the zombie-shooting heartthrob ugly.

Requiem for the dead. Nightmare for the living.
Grace Ashcroft and Leon S. Kennedy join the amiibo family in summer 2026.

Amiibo will be sold separately. pic.twitter.com/zOfUuU3IH3

‚Äî Resident Evil (@RE_Games) February 5, 2026

That‚Äôs not to say that the Grace Ashcroft figure is much better. Both of them look like cheap wedding cake toppers. Amiibos typically feature more stylized characters like most of Nintendo‚Äôs heroes, so they don‚Äôt often have to be very detailed. Resident Evil Requiem, however, is a photorealistic game that would lend itself to a more detailed statue. These figures‚Äô faces are so generic-looking that if it weren‚Äôt for Leon‚Äôs distinctive swooping hair, I probably would have a hard time identifying him. And trust me, I‚Äôve looked at his face extensively for decades. Where is his old man scruff?

‚ÄúReading the comments I feel like I‚Äôm taking crazy pills, but I must admit I‚Äôm not familiar with Amiibo and their usual quality,‚Äù Nexxtic wrote on Reddit. ‚ÄúAre they always this‚Ä¶ rough? I think these look pretty bad, especially Leon. Like one of those bad Switch ports.‚Äù

‚ÄúGrace seems nice, Leon a little less so,‚Äù wrote AdResponsible5888.

If nothing else, the existence of a Leon amiibo‚Äîa goofy looking one at that‚Äîmeans we get good jokes. Even if a lot of them have the same punchline.

Hopefully these aren‚Äôt the expensive $40+ amiibo, and are in the $15-20 range. They‚Äôre both coming out after Requiem‚Äôs launch, with the game itself arriving later this month on February 27 and both figures launching in the summer.
